reviews.text: Stayed at Te Tiare May 6-12. We had a great stay. The area is beautiful, the room was clean, the grounds were well maintained. It was private, quite, safe and very relaxing. This is not the type of place for people who like to "do" a lot as its pretty remote.
reviews.title: Perfect vacation start!

reviews.text: We stayed in Beach Bungalow #8, which is away from the bar and the restaurant. The best thing about it was this really great tree that gave us shade on the beach when we needed it and on the deck in the late afternoon. The room was big. Its not super-fancy but it was fine. The bathroom is really large and functional.
reviews.title: Loved Te Tiare

reviews.text: The beach is nice but small. Ok snorkeling off the beach. We took the kayak and the outrigger out exploring. Best "activity" we did was we took the outrigger to the wave break and snorkeled there all day. It was awesome. Very clear, pristine water, nobody else around, saw sharks, eels, octopus, a couple of rays, many fish, great coral.
reviews.title: A Little Piece of Heaven on Earth
Quiet and Pleasant Stay
reviews.text: The food at the restaurant was good but it had a somewhat limited menu for a 6 night stay. We had the breakfast and dinner plan. It was good and it made it much easier than trying to take the boat into town to find food there. If you like raw tuna, have the tuna carpaccio. We ate it every day! Service was good but very laid back.
This is a place to relax and kick back. It was a great place to start our vacation.
reviews.title: Absolute Paradise

reviews.text: My husband and I spent Dec 3-6 in #32 overwater bungalow. Wow, what a treat. The unit was very large, with a wonderful deck for lounging, reading books, drinking and watching sunsets. Being the physical fitness nut that I am, I couldn't believe I was enjoying the time there, relaxing and just spending one whole day in the water and around the bungalow. We snorkeled and used the kayaks, took a circle island tour one day and enjoyed the laid back island of Huahine. This hotel is clean and very nice, (there were no bugs), service was excellent. There is no commercialism on Huahine, so if you are seeking that for your vacation, look elsewhere. For the record, I am a travel professional and this is my second trip to French Polynesia.
reviews.title: Relaxing

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My new husband and I recently returned from a 2-week honeymoon in French Polynesia (Nov. 1-15, 2006). We stayed at Intercontinental Hotels in Tahiti, Moorea and Bora Bora, the Te Tiare Beach Resort on Huahine, Le Taha’a Private Island Resort and The Manihi Pearl Beach Resort. I’m posting my review of each property under that hotel and also want to give some general comments about French Polynesia that you may find helpful at the end of this review.
reviews.title: Awesome resort!

likes.disliked: — Little flakes of thatched roof fell when the wind blew

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Of the seven resorts my husband and I visited on our honeymoon in French Polynesia, the Te Tiare Beach Resort in Huahine is one of our favorites (our other favorite is Le Taha’a Private Island Resort). Huahine is as beautiful as many of the other islands but less developed and the Te Tiare Resort offers good value. Accessible only by boat, and with only 41 bungalows (11 Deep Water Bungalows, from $740/night; 5 Shallow Bungalows from $590/night; 6 Beachfront Bungalows, from $400/night; and 19 Garden Bungalows, from $335/night) the Ti Tiare Beach Resort is one of the most tranquil and romantic spots we encountered in French Polynesia.
reviews.title: True Spirit of French Polynesia

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our reservation said Lagoon Bungalow but since the water was at least 15 feet deep under our swimming platform, I think we may have been unknowingly upgraded to a Deep Overwater Bungalow. The large bungalows are comfortable without being over-the-top. They are a suite with living area, walk-in closet and partially covered wrap-around decks, complete with 2 lounges, a table and chairs and steps down to a swimming platform with a shower. The only downside was the ceiling shed little flakes of thatched leaf around the room when the wind blew, which weren’t a big deal but were noticeable on the bed and made the room feel a bit rustic. The bedspread seemed a little out-of-date, but otherwise the bungalow was very nicely appointed, including a TV, safe, American plugs, mini-bar, coffee maker and sink.
reviews.title: Tropical Alcatraz....Don't do it!!!!!

reviews.text: The staff blows a conch horn as guests arrive by boat transfer at the reception, built on a large dock over the lagoon, which also holds the lobby, restaurant and bar. The resort has one restaurant, the open-air Ari’i Restaurant (open 7-9:30am, noon-2pm, 7-9:30pm) and a beach bar only open for lunch. The resort also features a pool, internet kiosks (which cost about $8 for 15 minutes and are painfully slow), and activities desk. We went on a 2-hour horseback riding excursion one afternoon that was lots of fun. We were with 2 French couples and spent time on the beach, in a lagoon and riding along the roads where we got to trot and canter a few times (the brochure said we’d be riding Western but the tack was clearly English).
reviews.title: Relaxing
Where you will find the real polynesia !
reviews.text: A six year absence from the island of Huahine got the best of us.

reviews.title: Wonderful stay!
reviews.text: Tie to go back but to the question of where to stay, the answer was quite simple there, just 100% pure Tahiti!. One international class hotel the Te Tiare. ( Since the Sofitel Heiva has been cocooned in blue plastic shrink wrap).The other 2 properties worthy of consideration in a different classification were the Relais Mahana and Pension Mauarii both located on the south side of Huahine Iti. These properties have received mostly praises for the value for the money, superb lagoon and white sand beach and the great quality of the food served there. As you can see no 2500 rooms in 12 hotels like Bora Bora, no cruise liner in the lagoon, the pure essence of French polynesia with no artifacts.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: What a contrast the local scenery offers after a stay on Moorea.the island is manicured, grass and trees trimmed, hardly any traffic to speak of, paradise ! The local scene with mountains, pine trees and cows would normally say Switzerland until you reach the blue lagoon at the isthmus and stumble on to the vanil.la farms, taro plantations and banana trees.
reviews.title: got married here

likes.disliked: — the bed and no dvd or movies

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The representative of the Te Tiare picked us up at the airport, quick van drive to the pier, and a 15 minute boat ride to the Te Tiare ( no roads will take you to the property !). What a setting! Great gardens with my favorite traveller's tree, superb lagoon looking at Raiatea and Taha'a in front of the setting sun, great expanse of white sand beach with an ample supply of chaise lounge to enjoy each lazy minute in the sun.
reviews.title: OK -- not much to do, but beautiful setting

reviews.text: The Bungalow had until recently the distinction of offering french polynesia's largest in square footage, they are still the best available value for your money, large living room with a tv with at least 3 english speaking channels( but mind you CSI in french), a mini bar and coffee machine, very large bathroom with a bathtub/jaccuzi and separate shower, large deck with a gazebo and access to the 82 degree F lagoon to snorkel or swim. The hotel have among the most generous long stay discounts to invite any future traveller to make the most of each dollar spent and so with almost no seasonal restriction ( another rarity in the industry there ).
reviews.title: dreaming until the day we go back!
